meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of <kanji>未</kanji>, so it means the same thing: <vocabulary>not yet</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>still</vocabulary>, depending on the context.

The <kanji>standard</kanji> of <kanji>standard</kanji>s is the main <vocabulary>criterion</vocabulary> we work off of. That’s the <vocabulary>standard</vocabulary> we follow.

Compared to 基準 that's often a quantitative "standard" for assessment, 規準 is more of a quality-focused "criterion" that can be a basis for goals. You'll often see this word used in academic or professional contexts.

A certain <kanji>limit</kanji>’s <kanji>degree</kanji> is how far it can go. It’s the <vocabulary>limit</vocabulary>; turn it up one more degree and it’s out of <vocabulary>bounds</vocabulary>. Keep it right where it is and it’s perfect.

This word refers to the maximum extent or range of something, beyond which it cannot be surpassed. While similar to 限界, 限度 often implies a predetermined acceptable or tolerable limit, while 限界 is more closely associated with an absolute or ultimate limit.

When you can see <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>scene</kanji> you have a <vocabulary>complete view</vocabulary>.

This is not a common word in everyday conversations, but it can be found in literature, art, film, photography, and travel writing to describe a panoramic or comprehensive view of a scene.

The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>scene</kanji> is the <vocabulary>foreground</vocabulary>.

This word primarily refers to the visual foreground in art, photography, or theater. Unlike "foreground" in English, it’s not commonly used in a figurative sense to describe the most prominent aspect of situations.

This is the adverb version of 再, so it shares the meaning <vocabulary>again</vocabulary> and also has the meaning <vocabulary>once again</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is somewhat formal and literary.
You know how 来週 is <kanji>next week</kanji>? Well, if you do next week again, you have the <vocabulary>week after next</vocabulary>.

You learned that 故 means reason. Basically, whatever comes before 故に in a statement is going to be the reason for something that comes after. So 故に works like <vocabulary>therefore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>consequently</vocabulary>. It can also be translated as "because" or other similar conjunctions depending on the context.

Also keep in mind that 故に is mainly used in formal contexts, like in academic writing or politicians' speeches — just like "therefore" in English.
A <kanji>needle</kanji> made of <kanji>gold</kanji> is a <vocabulary>wire</vocabulary>. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess.

A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>big</kanji> thing is something that is <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gigantic</vocabulary>.

巨大 is often used in writing to describe something <vocabulary>enormous</vocabulary>. It can be for anything of immense scale, not just physical objects like buildings or monsters, but also abstract things like the impact of a natural disaster or even a person's influence.
A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is <vocabulary>a giant</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>beckon</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to beckon</vocabulary>. 

Since 招く conjures up the image of someone beckoning, it also means <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary>, and is a relatively formal word. Figuratively, it can also mean <vocabulary>to cause</vocabulary>, as in inviting some undesirable outcome or situation.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Reach The Extreme Of Something

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>extreme</kanji>. The verb vocab version isn't "to extreme" because that wouldn't make sense. Instead, you bring something to extremes, making this <vocabulary>to reach the peak of something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perfect</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reach the extreme</vocabulary>.

極める commonly means reaching the highest level of proficiency or excellence in a particular skill, art, or field. It can also mean taking something to the extreme, like being crazy busy.

meanings.meaning: To Reach The Peak Of Something

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>retreat</kanji>, and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to retreat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to withdraw</vocabulary>.

退く can also mean <vocabulary>to resign</vocabulary>, since resigning is a kind of a figurative retreat, like from a professional role or the forefront of some field or industry.

矢印 combines the kanji <kanji>arrow</kanji> and the vocab word 印 (mark), giving us the type of arrow you use for pointing at things, like these: →↑↓←. It could be an arrow on a sign, or on a piece of paper, or a document. We can just call it an <vocabulary>arrow</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>arrow symbol</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Line up</kanji> everything in a <kanji>row</kanji>. When you do that, they're all in <vocabulary>parallel</vocabulary>.

並列 is specifically used to describe items being arranged in a parallel way, like in parallel circuits or when vehicles are parked parallel to each other.

<kanji>Line up</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> together. If you did that, you'd be <vocabulary>in parallel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>going abreast</vocabulary> with someone.

並行 refers to two or more things placed or moving parallel to each other, like buses or trains running side by side. It's also used to describe two or more activities happening at the same time.

The kanji itself means <kanji>line up</kanji>, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, which makes this <vocabulary>to line up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lined up</vocabulary>. You can remember this because you keep saying <reading>boo</reading> (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? If you were the one in charge of lining things up, you wouldn't have <vocabulary>to stand in line</vocabulary> yourself…

Figuratively, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be on par</vocabulary>, as in someone or something matches or is comparable in ability, status, or ranking to another (as if they are aligned side by side in comparison).

The things that <kanji>line up</kanji> are <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>average</vocabulary> things. Because the majority of things (or people) fall into the average category, you could say most of them line up side by side with each other.

This might be why 並 is often used in restaurants to refer to standard (or average) portion sizes. And in sushi restaurants, 並 can refer to a standard set, as opposed to a more luxurious or premium one.

Note that when describing something as 並 outside of a restaurant or commercial context, it could have a slightly judgmental tone. Most people wouldn't love it if you called their work (or them) ordinary and average, you know?

A degree of <kanji>mastering</kanji> equal to a <kanji>samurai</kanji> is required for a <vocabulary>master's degree</vocabulary>. You'll have to master your chosen skill to the level of a samurai in order to obtain such a degree… Sounds tough.
When you <kanji>repair</kanji> things for a <kanji>reason</kanji>, you'll be able to <vocabulary>repair</vocabulary> just about anything! Just remember, always be repairing for a reason.

You <kanji>sharpen</kanji> your <kanji>mastering</kanji> of a specific skill. One could say that you're <vocabulary>training</vocabulary>. Additionally, when you sharpen someone else's mastering, you <vocabulary>give training</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>mastering</kanji> <kanji>word</kanji>s field of <kanji>study</kanji> is also known as <vocabulary>rhetoric</vocabulary>.

修辞学 is specifically for the study and theory of rhetoric. Rhetoric as an academic field, in other words. If you're just talking about the way people persuade each other with words, the more colloquial term is レトリック.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is when you take your <kanji>umbrella</kanji> and you <kanji>stand</kanji> it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an <vocabulary>umbrella stand</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>child</kanji> who is a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>child</vocabulary>. A group of them is <vocabulary>children</vocabulary>.

児童 refers specifically to children who are of elementary school age, typically from around 6 to 12 years old. It's often used in formal contexts, like in legal documents or when referring to <vocabulary>school children</vocabulary> in educational settings.

An <kanji>infancy</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>toddler</vocabulary>. The kanji are kind of deceptive since this isn't really used for infants. It's more for small children, from toddlers on up to <vocabulary>preschooler</vocabulary>s.

幼児 is sort of formal, but it's commonly used to talk about small children from about one to six years old, or about that specific period of early childhood.

Something that is <kanji>cool</kanji> is <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>. This refers to something that is <vocabulary>cold to the touch</vocabulary>, not the weather or something like that (which is 寒い).
You're <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>quiet</kanji>. That's you, daddio. Nice and <vocabulary>cool-headed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary>. So much <vocabulary>composure</vocabulary>

A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>frozen</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is one which is really cold on the inside, so cold it can freeze things. This is called a <vocabulary>freezer</vocabulary>, not to be confused with 冷蔵庫, which is refrigerator, and doesn't have the kanji for "freeze" in it.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frozen</kanji>, so the vocab version is <vocabulary>to freeze</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>frozen</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> isn't a bad way to go, I hear. Still, you don't want to <vocabulary>freeze to death</vocabulary> if you can help it.

Things that are <kanji>frozen</kanji> have been <kanji>tie</kanji>d up in <vocabulary>freezing</vocabulary> ice. They <vocabulary>get frozen</vocabulary> that way. 

凍結 is a relatively formal word that is used for the physical freezing of infrastructure, such as roads and water pipes. It can also refer to the freezing of systems or accounts, like the suspension of social media or bank accounts.

I can <kanji>deal with</kanji> it, no matter what the <kanji>reason</kanji>. I swear I can <vocabulary>deal with</vocabulary> this problem on my own!

処理 is a relatively formal word for <vocabulary>handling</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>processing</vocabulary> a problem or task to bring it to a resolution. It covers all kinds of tasks, from administrative work and data processing to practical challenges like waste disposal and complaint handling. It can even apply to defusing unexploded bombs.

When you <kanji>deal with</kanji> trash, you have to <kanji>divide</kanji> it into different types before you can get to its <vocabulary>disposal</vocabulary>. Whenever you deal with and divide something, you’re preparing to dispose of it.

処分 means getting rid of things you don’t want, like trash or old furniture. Sometimes, it can also mean <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>, like suspension from school for breaking the rules. This connection makes sense because both disposal and punishment involve handling something unwanted—whether it's an item or a behavior.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

券 is a standalone word that means <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>, but it's commonly used as a suffix to form words like 入場券 (admission ticket), 割引券 (discount <vocabulary>coupon</vocabulary>), or 定期券 (commuter <vocabulary>pass</vocabulary>).

Your <kanji>trip</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji> is the ticket that lets you go on ALL of your trips. It's not your airplane ticket, it's not your boat ticket, it's the trip ticket. It's your <vocabulary>passport</vocabulary>, which allows you to take trips.

旅券 is a formal term for a passport. It's commonly used in official documents and formal settings, like when dealing with government paperwork. In less formal contexts, you can simply say パスポート!

What's a <kanji>before</kanji> <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji>? It's a ticket you sell before an event. In other words, an <vocabulary>advance ticket</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>ticket sold in advance</vocabulary>!

前売り券 are often tickets with reduced prices and certain benefits or perks. Note that you'll also see this written as 前売券, without the okurigana, but the reading will stay the same.

Many <kanji>times</kanji> is how many times you can use this <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>ticket</kanji>s. That means there are many tickets, making this a <vocabulary>book of tickets</vocabulary>.

回数券 refers to a book or set of prepaid tickets that are often sold at a discount and can either be physical or digital. They are commonly used for public transportation, like buses or trains, and can also be issued by other businesses that people frequent, such as hot springs and public baths.
If 創造 is <kanji>creation</kanji> and you add <kanji>power</kanji> to it, you have <vocabulary>creative power</vocabulary>.
If 創造 is <kanji>creation</kanji>, then you add 的 to it, which means you have a creational thing, which is quite <vocabulary>creative</vocabulary> wouldn't you say?

An <kanji>exhibition</kanji> for <kanji>thing</kanji>s is put in a <kanji>public building</kanji> for anyone to see. This place is a <vocabulary>museum</vocabulary>.

Note that 博物館 isn't used for art museums, but for museums that focus on a wide range of other subjects, like natural history, science, history, and technology.

A <kanji>gambling</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary>.

占い is "fortune telling." <kanji>Star</kanji> <kanji>fortune</kanji> telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as <vocabulary>astrology</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>horoscope</vocabulary>.

Something that's both <kanji>delicate</kanji> and <kanji>peculiar</kanji> is probably <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>. It's not terrible, but it's not great either — it could break easily, plus it's kind of strange… It's <vocabulary>not really</vocabulary> good, you know? Think of 微妙 as a sort of euphemism for those delicate and peculiar things you're not really into. 

微妙 can also just mean <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>subtle</vocabulary>, like 微妙な立場 (a delicate position that requires careful handling) or 微妙なニュアンスの違い (a subtle nuance difference that's hard to pinpoint).

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 妙 is more often used in writing than conversation.
A <kanji>peculiar</kanji> <kanji>drug</kanji> that seems too good to be true? That's what we call a <vocabulary>wonder drug</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>miracle cure</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Lady</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is another way of saying <vocabulary>woman</vocabulary> — but kind of politely, you know? A way that's befitting of a <vocabulary>lady</vocabulary>.

婦人 is a polite but slightly old-fashioned word for an adult woman. You'll still often see it in formal category names, like 婦人服 (women's clothing) or 婦人科 (gynecology).
What do you call a <kanji>husband</kanji> and his <kanji>lady</kanji>? <vocabulary>Husband and wife</vocabulary>! They're a <vocabulary>married couple</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>infancy</kanji>. The adjective version describes someone who is <vocabulary>very young</vocabulary>, like little kids in their early childhood or babyhood!

Depending on the context, it can also describe behaviors or ideas that are <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> or immature, often with a negative connotation.

You have 時代 as a "period" of time you're talking about. What period? The <kanji>infancy</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s. Those years are not just when you're a baby, but when you were growing up, too. That was your <vocabulary>childhood</vocabulary>.

幼年時代 specifically refers to your <vocabulary>early childhood</vocabulary> years. It's a formal word you mostly see in writing with a slightly stiff tone, often appearing in literature, autobiographies, or memoirs looking back on someone's younger years.

The kanji means <kanji>storehouse</kanji>, and the vocab is also <vocabulary>storehouse</vocabulary>! Specifically, this usually refers to a traditional Japanese storehouse, which is typically a two story building used to store personal property or merchandise.

<kanji>Gold</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in <vocabulary>a safe</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>vault</vocabulary>.

金庫 can refer to various types of secure storage. Depending on the context, it can mean a personal safe, a bank vault, or a safety deposit box.

<kanji>Car</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is where you store your car. It's your <vocabulary>garage</vocabulary>.

車庫 literally means vehicle storage, so it's used for everything from home garages to large depots for public transportation. It carries a bit more of a formal tone than the katakana word ガレージ (garage).
回復 is <kanji>recovery</kanji>. Make it into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to recover</vocabulary>.

You've learned 微 can mean "delicate," but it can also mean <kanji>tiny</kanji>. Combine that with 生物, which you might remember is "living thing," and what do you get? A tiny living thing…? Well, that's a <vocabulary>microorganism</vocabulary>. The tiniest kind of living thing there is.
The <kanji>constitution</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji>s are what makes up the <vocabulary>constitution</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>constitution</kanji> <kanji>government</kanji> is a <vocabulary>constitutional government</vocabulary>.

憲政 is a formal word that might come up in discussions about democracy or constitutional frameworks, especially in advanced writing.

You already know that 無我 is "selflessness" and 夢中 is "crazy about." So this means something like <vocabulary>total absorption</vocabulary>. You're so into something that you’ve started losing your sense of self. Just like 夢中, this can also describe doing something <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary>ally, like running away from somebody or something.

The way your <kanji>body</kanji> <kanji>shake</kanji>s is how you use <vocabulary>body language</vocabulary> or how you <vocabulary>gesture</vocabulary>.

身振り generally refers to gestures in terms of body movements that make communication more expressive or help bridge language barriers. You'll often encounter this together with 手振り (hand gestures) in the phrase 身振り手振り.

振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to <vocabulary>furigana</vocabulary>, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go.

面接 is an <kanji>interview</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have to <vocabulary>interview with</vocabulary>.

Remember that 面接 is an interview for a job or admission to a school, not an interview for a magazine or a TV show. インタビューする is the more appropriate word for a media interview.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>to attack</kanji>, but 撃つ means <vocabulary>to shoot</vocabulary>.

This can mean <vocabulary>to fire</vocabulary> a weapon such as a gun or to shoot a projectile, like an arrow. It can also mean to shoot a person or animal.

With <kanji>aggression</kanji> you <kanji>attack</kanji> the enemy. This is an <vocabulary>attack</vocabulary>.

攻撃 usually refers to <vocabulary>attacking</vocabulary> someone or something with the intent of causing direct harm or damage, either physically or verbally. You'll hear it used in the context of war, games, arguments, or even things like media criticism or cyberattacks.

You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.

攻める means to attack or advance on an enemy in battle, but it can also apply to making a strong or proactive move in competitions like sports, business, or games. It can also be used to describe taking bold actions, like moving ahead with a risky plan.

Your <kanji>specialty</kanji>, which you focus on with <kanji>aggression</kanji>, is your <vocabulary>major</vocabulary> in college (your <vocabulary>college major</vocabulary>). Study hard, young grasshopper.
<kanji>Anti</kanji> <kanji>aggression</kanji> is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is ビーチ, and many people actually say 海 even though this literally means "sea."

It's the <kanji>side</kanji> of the <kanji>beach</kanji>! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: <vocabulary>Yokohama</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pure</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>.

Something so <kanji>pure</kanji> it's <kanji>pure</kanji> twice. It must be really <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>Cleanliness</vocabulary> is next to pure...liness, after all. I'm sure that's how the saying goes.

清潔 is a relatively formal word that refers to <vocabulary>sanitary</vocabulary> conditions in personal hygiene, public health, or medical settings. It can refer to both physically clean places and hygienic practices. In literature, 清潔 can also describe a person as morally pure.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>pure</kanji>, but this is an adjective that often describes behavior or character, so it means <vocabulary>honorable</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>dignified</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>gracious</vocabulary>.

How does that work? I guess if you can stay pure despite a tough situation, you must be pretty honorable and dignified. You're the type who can make a gracious apology (潔い謝り), have a dignified manner (潔い態度), or even die honorably (潔く死ぬ).

潔い is about being strong and doing the right thing without hesitation, especially when it's hard. For example, when someone admits their mistake honestly or handles a tough situation with courage, you can say they're 潔い. It's a way to praise someone for being straightforward and admirable in difficult times.

<kanji>Not</kanji> <kanji>clean</kanji> things are <vocabulary>filthy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dirty</vocabulary>. Ewughh.

不潔 is a relatively formal word that refers to <vocabulary>unsanitary</vocabulary> conditions in personal hygiene, public health, or medical settings. It can refer to both dirty environments and poor hygiene practices. In literature, 不潔 can also describe something as morally dirty to evoke disgust, though this use is somewhat old-fashioned.

Remember how 独り means "alone"? Well, if someone is alone and <kanji>say</kanji>ing something aloud, it constitutes <vocabulary>talking to oneself</vocabulary>.

独り言 means talking or muttering to yourself aloud, whether alone or in public. It can also refer to the words themselves — the things you say as you talk to yourself.

<kanji>Profit</kanji> and <kanji>benefit</kanji> literally means <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary>and <vocabulary>benefit</vocabulary>. Just like the English word "profit," it is often used to refer to financial gain, but can also be used for benefits that are non-financial as well.

To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>benefit</kanji> is to be <vocabulary>beneficial</vocabulary>.

有益 is a more formal word than 役に立つ (useful). It's often used for things like 有益なアドバイス (beneficial advice) or 有益な情報 (useful information).

Something for <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>benefit</kanji> is for <vocabulary>public benefit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>public interest</vocabulary>.

公益 is a formal word used to describe activities or organizations that have a positive impact on society or the general public.

The <kanji>country</kanji> will <kanji>benefit</kanji> from these actions. It will create <vocabulary>national benefit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>national interests</vocabulary>.

国益 is a word that is often found in formal political, diplomatic, and economic writing.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shift</vocabulary>.

When you're <kanji>shift</kanji>ing <kanji>peoples</kanji>, you're causing either <vocabulary>immigration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>emigration</vocabulary>, which leads to… <vocabulary>immigrant</vocabulary>s, or <vocabulary>emigrant</vocabulary>s.

If you <kanji>shift</kanji> the place you <kanji>dwell</kanji>, that's called <vocabulary>migration</vocabulary>.

移住 is a relatively formal word for the act of moving to a new place to live, often in a long-term or permanent sense. This word can mean moving to a new town or city, or it can refer to <vocabulary>immigration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>emigration</vocabulary> to a different country.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You'll see 程 used in all kinds of ways to express the <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> or degree of something, like 思った程じゃない (not as much as I expected), 言葉で表せない程すごい (so amazing it can't be expressed in words), or 30分程歩く (to walk for about thirty minutes). Just keep in mind this word is often written in kana.

The <kanji>extent</kanji>'s <kanji>degree</kanji> is the <vocabulary>degree</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> you're willing to take something.

程度 can also indicate an approximate <vocabulary>level</vocabulary>, like 一時間程度 (for about an hour) or この程度 (to this extent). To get a sense of the different uses, check out the context section.

<kanji>Surpass</kanji> the <kanji>extent</kanji>... okay, what does that even mean? You figure out the extent of your abilities, and then you surpass them to get better. You have to do this over and over again in order to keep getting better. It's a <vocabulary>process</vocabulary> that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now.

過程 is often used to describe ongoing progress, like 生産過程 (production process), but it can also be used to talk about how things develop. For example, you might reflect on the 過程 that led to your current job, or explain the steps a team follows to finish a project.

The <kanji>day</kanji>'s <kanji>extent</kanji> is that we're going to do this, this, and this. That is our <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>itinerary</vocabulary>, so stick to it.

日程 is a relatively formal word used to talk about the schedule for a specific event, meeting, or activity.

He who is both in his <kanji>infancy</kanji> and <kanji>immature</kanji> is probably <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>immature</vocabulary>.

When used as an adjective, 幼稚 describes negative immaturity in someone's behavior, remarks, or ideas. However, in compounds like 幼稚園 (kindergarten), it simply refers to the early childhood stage without any negative tone.

Your <kanji>spirit</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>spirit</vocabulary>. This word is for the human <vocabulary>mind</vocabulary> and can refer to your mental state, thinking, attitude, mindset, or even willpower. 

Depending on the context, 精神 can also mean "spirit" as in the essence or core principle of something, like 独立の精神 (the spirit of independence).

Your <kanji>spirit</kanji>'s <kanji>degree</kanji> of focus is what helps you to hone your <vocabulary>precision</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>accuracy</vocabulary>, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great precision you have gained by honing your spirit!

精度 is a relatively formal word, often used to talk about the precision or accuracy of something in technical or analytical contexts.

The kanji means <kanji>extinction</kanji> or <kanji>die out</kanji>, but the verb version here means <vocabulary>to break off contact</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to sever</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. Just think about how when you’re breaking off contact with somebody, you’re essentially making them go extinct or die out from your life completely. It’s such a complete severance, they basically stop existing to you.
お菓子 is "candy," right? Add <kanji>store</kanji> onto that and you have a <vocabulary>candy store</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>populous</kanji> place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the <vocabulary>general public</vocabulary>.

It's the <kanji>institution</kanji> that does <kanji>deliberation</kanji> on behalf of the <kanji>populace</kanji>. They represent the people. They are the <vocabulary>house of representatives</vocabulary>.
Remember how 貯金 means "savings"? Well, a <kanji>box</kanji> you put said savings in is a <vocabulary>savings box</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>piggy bank</vocabulary>.
比較 is a comparison. Add 的 to it and you have <vocabulary> comparatively</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Keep in mind that 逆 often implies something is the <vocabulary>reverse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>opposite</vocabulary> of what it should be. For example, you use 逆 when you're going in the opposite direction of your destination or wearing your shirt backwards.
効果 means "effect," so the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of said effect is the <vocabulary>opposite effect</vocabulary>. Or in other terms, something <vocabulary>counterproductive</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>opposite</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to go against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to oppose</vocabulary>.

逆らう refers to resisting natural or social forces, like 逆らって進む (to go against the tide), or to opposing specific people, like 親に逆らう (to defy one's parents). It means actively resisting something, whether it's a flow, a trend, or authority, highlighting a conscious choice to take a different path.

It is <kanji>reverse</kanji> to the <kanji>theory</kanji>! What is going on? Things aren't right. There must be some kind of <vocabulary>paradox</vocabulary> going on, where all theories are reversed! D:

A 間違い is a mistake. A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>mistake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>big mistake</vocabulary>.

大間違い is less about factual errors and more about someone being way off in their assumptions or expectations. It suggests things didn't go according to plan — like you assumed a smile would fix everything or expected a date to go well, only for things to turn out completely wrong.
With 郵便 being <kanji>mail</kanji> and 局 being bureau, we have the "mail bureau." They're more often known as the <vocabulary>post office</vocabulary>.

You know that a 郵便 is the <kanji>mail</kanji> and that a 番号 is a <kanji>number</kanji>. So a "mail number," what is that? Usually refers to your <vocabulary>post number</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>postal code</vocabulary>. It is also often referred to with a symbol, which is 〒, so look out for that.

郵便 is the "mail." A <kanji>box</kanji> that's used with said mail is a <vocabulary>postbox</vocabulary>.

郵便箱 used to refer specifically to a public <vocabulary>collection box</vocabulary> where you drop off your mail to be sent. But now, some people use it for their home <vocabulary>mailboxes</vocabulary> too! Don't worry — you can usually tell which is which from context.

A <kanji>record</kanji> of <kanji>sound</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sound recording</vocabulary> of some kind. Might be minidisk, might be CD, might be digital. Whatever it is, it's still the record of sound.

<kanji>Climb</kanji> up and <kanji>record</kanji> your information here. This is <vocabulary>registration</vocabulary>. It's work to get yourself registered (from the climbing) and even if you get your name recorded on there, you may not get in. So record your information, wait, and hope you get in.

<kanji>Write down</kanji> a <kanji>record</kanji> of the events so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary>, please. Don't want people to forget about this momentous occasion, when King Felix got his perfect game.

記録 refers to the act of putting something on record or to the record itself. Just like English "record," it can also refer to the best performance or most remarkable event of its kind that's been officially measured and noted, like the record for fastest baseball pitch.

The <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>squad</kanji> is <vocabulary>an army</vocabulary>. It's also just the <vocabulary>army</vocabulary>. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

隊 is commonly used as a suffix to refer to an organized group or unit, often one that works together toward a specific goal or purpose, like a レスキュー隊 (rescue <vocabulary>squad</vocabulary>), 軍の部隊 (military <vocabulary>unit</vocabulary>), or 登山隊 (mountaineering <vocabulary>team</vocabulary>)!

A <kanji>soldier</kanji> in a <kanji>squad</kanji> is a real <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sailor</vocabulary>, unlike those "soldier" who are not in a squad. They don't have jobs, and can't be called real soldiers.

<kanji>Enter</kanji>ing into a <kanji>squad</kanji> is called <vocabulary>enlistment</vocabulary>!

入隊 can refer to <vocabulary>enlist</vocabulary>ing in any group that ends with 隊 (squad), like the 軍隊 (military) or an 音楽隊 (marching band). These are indeed the most common uses.

Remember how <ja>痛い</ja> is "painful"? This is the verb version of that, so it means <vocabulary>to ache</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hurt</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in pain</vocabulary>.

痛む is an intransitive verb that suggests an ongoing sensation of pain or aching. It's a little more descriptive than 痛い, so you might see it used in writing or to describe a more persistent or recurring condition. It's also often used figuratively, especially in expressions like 心が痛む (my heart aches).

<kanji>Drowsy</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>medicine</kanji> sounds a little goofy, but it's exactly what you'd expect it to be: <vocabulary>sleeping pills</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleeping medication</vocabulary>.
If 誘惑 is seduction or temptation, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to seduce</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tempt</vocabulary>.
輸入 is <kanji>import</kanji>. Now let's make it a verb. <vocabulary>To import</vocabulary>.

我 is me, so two of me makes <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>us</vocabulary>!

You've learned that 我 is an old-fashioned pronoun. 我々 is similar in that it feels formal and authoritative. This means it's often used in situations that require official representation, like company statements, business meetings, or political speeches. Check out our context sentences for some examples!

直接 means "direct." Add 的 to the mix and you have <vocabulary>directly</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word, so you'll encounter other words like ダイレクト in more casual contexts.

Things that are <kanji>beautiful</kanji> and <kanji>lovely</kanji> are very <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>pretty</vocabulary>, and often <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, too. You can call someone 綺麗. You can also mention how clean something is with 綺麗. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.

Wondering what the difference is between 綺麗 and 美しい? 美しい is more dramatic, so it implies you’re really blown away by something’s (or someone’s) beauty. 綺麗, on the other hand, is a more everyday word that covers anything that’s beautiful, pretty, or even just clean. In other words, the bar is a bit lower for 綺麗!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this word means something closer to <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come down</vocabulary>.

降る is commonly used when talking about the weather, like 雨が降る (it rains) or 雪が降る (it snows). It also applies to other things falling from above, like 火山灰が降る (volcanic ash falls) or even figuratively, as in 幸運が降ってくる (good luck comes your way).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>droop</kanji>, so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to droop</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hang down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>. So you can use 垂れる to describe your dog's floppy ears hanging down or your ice cream’s melty goodness dripping away.

垂れる is generally intransitive, but it can also take a direct object in specific expressions, like 説教を垂れる (to give a preachy lecture), こうべを垂れる (to bow one's head in humility), or the crude slang クソを垂れる (to drop a load).

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that, unlike English, which differentiates between different types of wetlands like marshes, swamps, or bogs, Japanese 沼 refers to any pond-like areas with muddy, murky water.
A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> place is a place where the earth is boggy. That's a <vocabulary>marshland</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wetland</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>attack</kanji>! This is a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> on someone or something, though it can also be an <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
Remember how 兄弟 means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to <kanji>obey</kanji> they're not your brother or sister, they're your <vocabulary>cousin</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>long for</kanji> something you'll get feelings of <vocabulary>yearning</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>longing</vocabulary>. Don't worry, some day you'll get whatever it is. 

憧れ can also describe a strong feeling of <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary>, particularly for people.
A <kanji>beach</kanji> <kanji>area</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>beach</vocabulary>!

This is like saying "when it comes to the 何故," which means you're giving a reason, making this <vocabulary>because</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the reason is</vocabulary>, followed by… whatever you wanna say! 

Note that this is a quite formal way to say "because," so you'll mostly encounter this in writing or formal speech, and almost always at the beginning of a sentence in Japanese.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Make A Mistake On Something

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mistake</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive. That means that it takes a direct object. Bear in mind that this one is a bit tricky, though, because although it's transitive in Japanese, the English translation will sometimes be intransitive.
<kanji>Shift</kanji> and <kanji>move</kanji> to create <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>untie</kanji> something that's <kanji>frozen</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>thawing</vocabulary> it. The best way to go about <vocabulary>defrosting</vocabulary> anything is always to untie it first.

In the context of computer files, this word can also mean <vocabulary>unzipping</vocabulary>. We unzip files in English, but in Japanese we thaw them!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb that uses the <kanji>complete</kanji> kanji. It means <vocabulary>to be complete</vocabulary>. It can also be used when you want things <vocabulary>to be uniform</vocabulary>. It feels satisfying to have everything complete and uniform, right?
The <kanji>north</kanji>ern <kanji>extreme</kanji> of the world is the <vocabulary>North Pole</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Arctic</vocabulary>. You know, the pole with the polar bears.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>twist</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to twist</vocabulary>.

捻る literally means "to twist," so you can use it for everything from turning the handle of a faucet to twisting your ankle in a soccer game. When combined with other words, it can also take on metaphorical meanings, such as 頭を捻る (to think hard) and 首を捻る (to puzzle over).

We have <kanji>night</kanji> and the noun version of 更ける (to grow late). Stick the two together, and you get a word that means <vocabulary>late at night</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>dead of night</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>wee hours</vocabulary>.
